posts.name:
‚ö°Ô∏è Bianca B. King
‚ö°Ô∏è Bianca B. King
posts.content:
"Call in rich." 

That's what we said we would do.

Back in my corporate days, that was the joke we shared.

We‚Äôd dream about winning the lotto, walking into work with our resignation letters, and saying, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm out.‚Äù

With many companies eliminating the work-from-home option;
I'm sure this is on a lot of people's minds.

Yes, the $150M jackpot would have been very nice.

But for me, it was about freedom.
Freedom from calendars filled with other people‚Äôs priorities.
Freedom to spend my days building my dream life.

But here's truth: you don‚Äôt need the lotto to access that freedom.
Today, you can start designing a life on your terms.

Start small.
Ô∏è Take the PTO.
Ô∏è Start your side hustle.
Ô∏è Say no more often.

Choose goals that align with your values, not someone else‚Äôs checklist.

Because the richest lives?
They aren‚Äôt measured in dollars because money is just a tool.
They‚Äôre measured in joy, purpose, and time spent doing what matters most.

So today, what‚Äôs one small shift you can make toward your version of ‚Äúcalling in rich‚Äù?

P.S. Want to take this mindset and put it into action
Join me and the 10 other speakers at the 2025 Level Up Summit.

It's an incredible space to learn, connect, and reimagine your success on your terms. Link in comments.

comments.commentText: I know that's right Ô∏è Bianca B. King. I'm calling in rich, wealthy and generational wealth!

posts.name:
Matthew Buchalski
Matthew Buchalski
posts.content:
Promoting too soon might be a sign of a recruiting problem.

Here‚Äôs something to think about: When you promote someone too quickly, is it because they earned it, or because you don‚Äôt have any other options?

To be clear, I firmly believe that companies should develop their people and promote them from within. But, building top-performing sales teams often requires a blend of internal & external hiring.

The 2023 @The Bridge Group Sales Development Report revealed some eye-opening trends:

Ô∏èThe average tenure for SDRs fell to 1.4 years in 2022, breaking a multi-year trend.
Ô∏èProductivity = Tenure - Ramp. Once you subtract ramp time, the median SDR only spends 16 months at full productivity before moving on.

Here‚Äôs why that matters:

If you‚Äôre promoting reps too soon, you may be robbing your team of critical development productivity time.

And it‚Äôs often because you‚Äôre covering up a recruiting issue‚Äîthe absence of a robust candidate funnel that can fill the open reqs needed to hit the sales plan.

A premature promotion doesn‚Äôt fix the problem. It creates new ones:

Ô∏èTeams get burned out when they lack strong performers. Or when junior teams are pilfered for early recruits
Ô∏èYou promote reps before they‚Äôre ready, but they flounder in next-level roles, ultimately putting more pressure on the system.
Ô∏èYour talent pipeline suffers because you lose productive contributors too quickly.

Instead of rushing people up the ladder, ask yourself:

Ô∏èIs our recruiting strategy effective in bringing in a funnel of high-quality candidates?
Ô∏èAm I hiring people who can ramp up fast, deliver results, and stay long enough to truly make an impact?
Ô∏èAre the recruiting AND leadership teams doing enough joint outreach to external top performers to build a talent bench?
Ô∏èIs your company‚Äôs social brand solid enough to attract the best talent?

Hire the right people, set them up for success, and give them time to own their role. One-quarter of successful performance after ramp does not automatically make someone promotion-worthy.

Promotions should be earned‚Äînot used to paper over gaps.

Because a rushed promotion today might mean bigger problems tomorrow.

posts.name:
Brij kishore Pandey
Brij kishore Pandey
posts.content:
Life is short... write Python!

Python is not just a programming language‚Äîit's your gateway to infinite possibilities.

Whether you're automating mundane tasks or building the next AI breakthrough, Python's simplicity and power make it the perfect companion.

Here's my battle-tested roadmap to Python mastery (with realistic time commitments):

1. Foundation (1 Month, 1 hour daily)
‚Ä¢ Master Python syntax, control flow & functions
‚Ä¢ Get comfortable with data structures & OOP
‚Ä¢ Learn essential tools: virtual environments, pip & Git

2. Intermediate Journey (2 Months, 1 Hour daily)
‚Ä¢ Dive into web scraping & API integration
‚Ä¢ Conquer databases & testing
‚Ä¢ Explore async programming & popular libraries

3. Advanced Territory (1 Month, 2+ hours daily)
‚Ä¢ Build with web frameworks (Django/Flask)
‚Ä¢ Explore data science (Pandas, NumPy, Matplotlib)
‚Ä¢ Deploy to cloud & containerize applications
‚Ä¢ Master CI/CD & optimization

Tips for Success:
‚Ä¢ Build 2-3 real projects in each phase
‚Ä¢ Join the open-source community
‚Ä¢ Connect with Python enthusiasts on Discord/Reddit
‚Ä¢ Study popular codebases
‚Ä¢ Document your journey
‚Ä¢ Remember to take breaks!

Consistency trumps intensity. 10 focused hours/week will take you further than cramming 10 hours in two days!

What's your take on this roadmap?

comments.commentText: Python is like a universal language for data handling and manipulation! Everything connects with it at least to some degree.

posts.name:
Sarah Touzani
Sarah Touzani
posts.content:
Want to know what kills company culture instantly?

Your team wayching laid-off colleagues get ghost

Last week they were:
‚Ä¢ In every team meeting
‚Ä¢ Part of every celebration
‚Ä¢ Grabbing coffee with you
‚Ä¢ Solving problems together

Then the layoff hits.

Suddenly they're:
‚Ä¢ Off Slack
‚Ä¢ Out of meetings
‚Ä¢ Removed from email
‚Ä¢ And apparently off-limits for contact?

That last part?
That's on us.

Here's what most people do:
‚Ä¢ Avoid reaching out ("It's awkward")
‚Ä¢ Stop engaging ("Don't know what to say")
‚Ä¢ Ghost completely ("Maybe it's better this way")

Here's what leaders do:
‚Ä¢ Send a direct message
‚Ä¢ Keep in touch
‚Ä¢ Share opportunities
‚Ä¢ Make introductions
‚Ä¢ Offer to be a reference

It's not complicated.
It's not time-consuming.
It's just being kind.

The reality is:
Your team is watching.
They're taking notes.
They're seeing exactly how disposable relationships are.

Want to destroy psychological safety?
Show your team that friendship expires with employment.

Want to build trust?
Show them you value people over positions.

Three things you can do today:
1. Message someone who was laid off
2. Share their "open for work" post
3. Introduce them to one person

Your culture isn't your ping pong table.
It's how you treat people when things get hard.

What's one thing you wish people did for you during a layoff?

‚¨áÔ∏è Share below

Repost to spread this behaviour
Followfor real talk on building healthy teams

posts.name:
Business Development - The Missing Link Between Marketing & Sales - 540,000 Members Strong
Business Development - The Missing Link Between Marketing & Sales - 540,000 Members Strong
posts.content:
Fitting In vs. Belonging: A Hard Truth

Have you ever felt like you fit in perfectly,

but something still didn‚Äôt feel right?

That was me in one of my previous roles.

I excelled at my work.

I got along with my team.

I was "in the right place," or so it seemed.

But deep down, I knew something was missing.

I realized fitting in wasn‚Äôt enough.

I wanted to belong somewhere my values aligned.

Where my work had meaning beyond a paycheck.

So, I took the leap.

What I Learned:

Fitting In Is About Conformity
You adapt to the culture, even if it doesn‚Äôt fit you.

Belonging Is About Alignment
It‚Äôs where your purpose matches the place.

The Right Place Energizes You
You feel valued, challenged, and inspired to grow.

When I found that place, everything changed.

I wasn‚Äôt just "working"; I was thriving.

The Takeaway:

Fitting in feels safe, but belonging transforms you.

Are you settling for comfort,

or are you chasing purpose?

comments.commentText:
Absolutely agree with this! The distinction between fitting in and belonging is such an eye-opener. Fitting in can feel like wearing a mask ‚Äì it works on the surface, but deep down, it drains you. Belonging, on the other hand, is when you feel truly seen and aligned with the environment around you.
Your point about belonging being energizing is spot on. It‚Äôs not just about being in the right place but being in a space where your values, purpose, and work truly connect. When that happens, you‚Äôre not just surviving‚Äîyou‚Äôre thriving.
This post is such a powerful reminder to reflect: Am I adapting to fit in, or am I embracing my authenticity to belong? Thank you for sharing this insightful perspective‚Äîit‚Äôs a much-needed reminder for so many of us!
